cmCourseInfo.description:
An introduction to the main elements of the Italian language. The development of speaking, reading, and writing skills. Introduction to Italian culture and texts.

A questionnaire on students' knowledge of and background in Italian will be administered shortly before or during the first class.
cmCourseInfo.title: Italian Language for Beginners
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Grade 11 and/or 12 Italian (U or M level) or previous experience or instruction in Italian.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course features the flipped classroom method.

Delivery Instructions

This course also features a shared, pre-recorded asynchronous component delivered online to all students in the course. This component will take on average about one hour per week. This section of the course is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule, but students will have to complete it before the active learning sessions of the course (consisting of 3 hours per week), which are live-streamed, delivered synchronously per the meeting schedule. 

If section is identified as online synchronous, then students need to use several functions within Quercus (Discussion Boards, BB Collaborate), the ability to use MS Teams and/or Zoom for interactive sessions, a webcam, and a microphone. Students are expected to keep cameras on all the time.

courses.name: The Fine Art of Murder: Reading Detective Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: Since its inception in the Nineteenth century, detective fiction has been one of the most popular literary genres, proving adept at both entertaining and shining a critical light on social and political problems. This course will explore the many faces of detective fiction addressing questions such as: Why does crime hold such a fascination for modern audiences? What kind of pleasure do we derive from reading stories that often follow established conventions and rules? What do these novels about crime and punishment tell us about broader social and political issues? Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Fine Art of Murder: Reading Detective Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of Machiavelli’s political doctrine in The Prince and the development of his ideas in politics, ethics and the arts. Special attention will be paid to the enduring relevance of his legacy in the modern world. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Machiavelli and Machiavellianism

courses.name: Italian Fascism and Global Responses: The Dark Side of Italianità

cmCourseInfo.description: After WWI, Italian society faced a political, economic, and moral crisis that resulted in the rise of fascism. Using diverse sources (media, literary texts, movies, architecture and design); this course explores various reactions in Italy and abroad to the rise of Mussolini and the totalitarian State. Why did common people, intellectuals, politicians, and business and community leaders around the globe succumb to the seduction of fascism? How did other people denounce fascist violence? After an introduction to Italian fascism, the course will consider global reactions to Italian fascism and diverse responses in Italian communities abroad (e.g. Canada, USA, Argentina). Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Italian Fascism and Global Responses: The Dark Side of Italianità

courses.name: Major Italian Authors in Translation: from Dante to Tasso

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will focus on authors from the Middle Ages to the Renaissance who had a defining influence on Western literature, such as Dante, Petrarca, Boccaccio, Machiavelli, Ariosto and Tasso. This course includes a component designed to enhance students’ research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Major Italian Authors in Translation: from Dante to Tasso

courses.name: Major Italian Authors in Translation: from Marino to Calvino

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will focus on authors from the Baroque to the Twentieth Century who had a defining influence on Western literature, such as Marino, Goldoni, Manzoni, Pirandello, Calvino. This course includes a component designed to enhance students’ research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Major Italian Authors in Translation: from Marino to Calvino

cmCourseInfo.description:
This course surveys the history of Italian cinema and the sociopolitical circumstances surrounding the film industry, from its early days to the present, while also introducing the students to methods of analysis and research appropriate to the field. Emphasis will be placed on films from the silent era to the 1960s, and from the 1960s to the present. This course includes a component designed to introduce students to methods of scholarly research appropriate to the field.

The course is given in English and all films shown have English subtitles.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of Italian Cinema

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and any discussions and/or activities will be delivered online synchronously per the meeting schedule. Students will need to use several functions within Quercus (Discussion Boards) and the ability to use MS Teams and/or Zoom. It is necessary that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. Screenings will be asynchronous and students are responsible to watch the films on their own time.

cmCourseInfo.description:
Grammar review, readings of Italian authors and oral practice to enhance comprehension and expressive skills.

Students without the prerequisite will be asked to fill out a questionnaire on their knowledge of and background in Italian.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Italian
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ITA100Y1/ITA151Y1; Grade 11 and/or 12 Italian (U or M level); or previous experience or instruction in Italian, or permission of the Department.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course features the flipped classroom method.

Delivery Instructions

This course also features a shared, pre-recorded asynchronous component delivered online to all students in the course. This component will take on average about one hour per week. This section of the course is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule, but students will have to complete it before the active learning sessions of the course (consisting of 3 hours per week), which are live-streamed, delivered synchronously per the meeting schedule. 

If the section is identified as online synchronous, then students need to use several functions within Quercus (Discussion Boards, BB Collaborate), the ability to use MS Teams and/or Zoom for interactive sessions, a webcam, and a microphone. Students are expected to keep cameras on all the time.

cmCourseInfo.description: “Made in Italy” is a global standard for creativity and excellence in fashion, architecture, and industrial design. This course will explore how art, imagination, and craft have intersected in different areas of Italian culture over time. Based on an individual instructor’s area of expertise, themes explored may include studies of the Italian fashion industry, food culture, commercial art, and industrial design. Primary materials will include artworks, literary texts, material objects, and mixed media that demonstrate the importance of design culture in Italy and the impact of Italian design culture in the world. This course includes a component designed to enhance students’ research experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Italian Design: Fashion, Artistry, Genius

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Like spoken languages, the food system contains and conveys the culture of its practitioner; it is the repository of traditions and of collective identity.” (Massimo Montanari, Food is Culture). This course will explore a broad range of topics related to food, including a socio-historical analysis of the movement of food trends in Italy, the contribution of Italian immigration to other cultures’ cuisines, the popularity of Italian gastronomical standbys such as the aperitivo, and what modern culinary phenomena such as Starbucks and Eataly take from authentic Italian culinary traditions, as well as what they leave out. This course will include an interdisciplinary component, examining Italian food culture in its various artistic forms, through cinema, literature, lanuage and television. Buon appetito!

courses.name: Sex and Gender in Contemporary Italy

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will focus on theoretical and cultural productions that deal with issues of sexuality and gender in (contemporary) Italy. Based on an individual instructor’s area of expertise, themes explored may include feminism and women’s rights, sexual liberation and LGBTQ+ rights, Queer-of-Colour critique, and other topics within the study of sexual and gender diversity. Primary materials will include manifestos, theoretical essays, novels, short stories, and films that deal with gender and sexual diversity in the Italian-speaking world and from a transnational perspective. Linguistic issues will also be discussed. This course includes a component designed to enhance students’ research experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sex and Gender in Contemporary Italy

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:

cmCourseInfo.description: The focus of this course is the films of Italian Neorealism, one of the most influential, artistic, and intellectual movements in the history of world cinema. While emphasis will be placed primarily on the work of Roberto Rossellini, Vittorio De Sica, and Luchino Visconti, the course will also offer a detailed discussion of the historical context and of the sociopolitical issues of postwar Italy. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Italian Neorealist Cinema

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Screenings will be asynchronous and students are responsible to watch the films on their own time before class.

cmCourseInfo.description:
For students who have completed ITA250Y1/ITA251Y1. Discussion of problems of grammar, style, and composition. Language analysis based on readings of Italian authors. One hour a week of oral practice. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience.

Students without the prerequisite(s) will be asked to fill out a questionnaire on their knowledge of and background in Italian.
cmCourseInfo.title: Language Practice

notes.name: Course Note

This course features the flipped classroom method.

Delivery Instructions

This course also features a shared, pre-recorded asynchronous component delivered online to all students in the course. This component will take on average about one hour per week. This section of the course is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule, but students will have to complete it before the active learning sessions of the course (consisting of 3 hours per week), which are live-streamed, delivered synchronously per the meeting schedule. 

If the section is identified as online synchronous, students need to use several functions within Quercus (Discussion Boards, BB Collaborate), the ability to use MS Teams and/or Zoom for interactive sessions, a webcam, and a microphone. Students are expected to keep cameras on all the time.

cmCourseInfo.description: Starting with a survey of the sociolinguistic situation in Italy before Unification, this course deals with the complex relationship between regional languages and dialects on the one hand and Common Italian on the other. The recent rise of regional variants of Italian and its impact on the dialects are also discussed. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Italian Sociolinguistics

cmCourseInfo.description: An open course that explores specific aspects of Italian Studies. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Italian Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: An open course that explores specific aspects of Italian Studies. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Italian Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

LEC0101 Description: In this course we will explore several forms of cultural productions made by Italians of African descent in the past thirty years. Ranging from writers, scholars, musicians, poets, visual artists, cultural influencers, fashion designers, journalists and many more; the course will show the complexities of contemporary Italy and will analyse tensions and frictions characterizing the political and cultural discourse on race, gender and sexuality, identity, and citizenship.

cmCourseInfo.description: An open course that explores specific aspects of Italian Studies. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Italian Studies

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 7, 2021: Section Number changed, Meeting Time added.

cmCourseInfo.description: A course on specific topics in Italian Studies, designed for advanced students. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience. (Given in English)
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Italian Studies

courses.name: Italian Language and Italian Dialects in Toronto

cmCourseInfo.description: Through an historical overview of Italian immigration in Toronto, the role of Italian and Italian dialects in the city will be examined. As part of the topic studied in course, students will contribute to the website of the OIM by collecting varied forms of empirical linguistic evidence.
cmCourseInfo.title: Italian Language and Italian Dialects in Toronto

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
July 12, 2021: Course added.
September 30, 2021: Delivery Method Changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will focus on the writings of women in different periods of Italian history. Spanning a variety of genres, from the novel to autobiography, from poetry to essayism, the course will discuss various aspects of the debate regarding the changing roles of women in society. This course includes a component designed to enhance students' research experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Women Writers in Italy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ITA250Y1/ITA251Y1, and at least 0.5 FCE ITA literature courses at the 300-level

cmCourseInfo.description: An opportunity to pursue at the 400-level an independent course of study not otherwise available. A written proposal, co-signed by the instructor, must be submitted on the appropriate proposal form for approval by the Department of Italian Studies. Application deadline: April 30 for F courses, November 30 for S courses.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: An opportunity to pursue at the 400-level an independent course of study not otherwise available. A written proposal, co-signed by the instructor, must be submitted on the appropriate proposal form for approval by the Department of Italian Studies. Application deadline: April 30 for F courses, November 30 for S courses.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: In exceptional circumstances, students may request to pursue at the 400-level an independent course of study not otherwise available. A written proposal, co-signed by the instructor, must be submitted on the appropriate proposal form for approval by the Department of Italian Studies. Application deadline April 30.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Based on a professor’s research project currently in progress, this course will enable an undergraduate student to play a useful role in the project while receiving concrete training in research. This course is mandatory for all students enrolled in the specialist’s program.
cmCourseInfo.title: Directed Research
